ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments:
Recorded seminars were also used
Glossaries alive (online textbook / interactive website)
The classes would be live every day, but they would also be posted on Canvas to view later.
On Fridays, students participated in a conversation section. This consisted of a brief quiz proctored over zoom and a discussion in Hindi about various class topics.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
- The basics of Hindi! (subjects, various verbs, objects, DO's, IO's, writing, reading, basic communication...)
- How to write and read in Devanagri script
- How to interpret much of what is said in Bollywood movies and song
- Lots of songs in Hindi! 
- How to communicate with classmates / family on a basic but relatively fluid level

I learned how to write Hindi in a variety of different tenses and use a variety of vocabulary. I also learned how to read and speak in Hindi and those skills greatly improved over the course of the semester. I could observe a noticeable difference in my reading and speaking skills, although it was harder to gauge my writing skills due to the nature of it being over Zoom.

Throughout this course, I developed basic skills for communicating in Hindi. I learned how to write in the script commonly used for the language in India and around the world. I learned how to introduce myself, to respond to various commands, and to communicate basic needs. This course introduced me to aspects of Indian cultures and fomented my love of the Hindi language.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths
- The instructors! Seema Jee and Swapna Jee were so incredible!!
- Presentation of course material (organized and interesting)
- Pace of the course (well suited for new students to the language)
- Weekly quizzes kept students on track and made for stronger conversation at the end of the semester
- Magazine project (a way to tie together all of our skills!)
- Availability of resources made available to us
-Songs / Incorporation of cultural events (Diwali, Film, Etc) into class discussions

Weaknesses

A strength of the course is that it provides a low-stress environment for those that are completely new to the language to feel comfortable and develop their skills. The instructors are also very nice and encouraging. A weakness of the course is sometimes I was not really sure how assignments were being graded.

This course has many strengths, chief among which is the engagement of the professors with the students. Beginning to try to express myself in a different language and in an unfamiliar context was anxiety-inducing, but my close relationship with Seema Ji and Swapna Ji quickly helped to alleviate my fears. I Would only make one suggestion for altering the course: I think it would be beneficial if students had the opportunity to speak in Hindi more in smaller settings, perhaps structured time to engage with conversation partners or a TA.

Strengths: Warmth and personability of Swapna ji, Seema ji, and Chitra, incredibly inclusive/welcoming learning environment, songs to keep us engaged, unique/challenging midterm and final projects, journal entry exercises.

Weaknesses: At times seemed a bit disorganized and was sometimes difficult to find things on Canvas. Writing out a weekly learning portfolios didn't seem very useful on my end.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In my opinion, the class was taught as well as possible given the online format! The professors did a great job adapting to the virtual space. Question and answer during live sessions were incredibly useful in enhancing student knowledge on the subjects. I think the whiteboards are great to use, and perhaps could have been used more while learning the Devanagri script (there is an annotate feature which allows students in the class to also write on the professors whiteboard simultaneously  -- it might be good to help new students write the script in class to simulate using the chalkboards in person! )

I felt that the course format moved seamlessly to the online medium. I recognize that the experience of singing, talking, making introductions, and eating food was significantly diminished online, but I was still immensely satisfied by the course.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely!! Hindi has the best professors and is super well organized to help learn the language in a short period of time!

I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in Indian culture and history or the Hindi language specifically, but also to students who are interested more broadly in the study of language. The instructors successfully represented both a strong linguistic treatment of the language as well as the experience that linguistic rules are insufficient to convey. The courseload was regular but low, and the word was easily manageable but stayed engaging throughout the semester.
Yes! The Hindi department is great. This class was a perfect introduction. Looking forward to the next semester.
